But after a few weeks that fell off, and I was back to the knits and jeans. “At that point, my wardrobe had morphed into this casual world,” he continued. “It would've required an investment to go fully in the direction of polished and dressed up.” Clothing has always played a pivotal role in our working lives. “The golden age of uniform is undoubtedly the first half of the 20th century,” says Jane Tynan, a cultural historian at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, who edited the bookUniform: Clothing and Discipline in the Modern World. “Uniforms were adopted by most large organizations to extract loyalty from workers—this standardized dress was an early form of branding.” An all-occasions style guide for the weekly grind with nary a stretchy chino in sight. There’s long been a tension between freedom, autonomy, and self-expression in the way we dress for work. Are workers gaining power when they ditch their suits for athleisure? Or are they merely attempting to flex the small amount of independence they have, in the face of employers clawing them back to a 9-to-5 office experience? The relationship between our personal and professional lives—and how that’s expressed through clothing—has always been a fashion world obsession. The late-aughtsMad Mencraze, for instance,inspireda 2008 Michael Kors collection. Or consider Thom Browne’s2009 Pitti Uomo presentation, in which an army of identically dressed office drones entered a drab workplace en masse and sat clacking their typewriters in unison before leaving. As a culture we’ve long read into the symbolism of Mark Zuckerberg'szip-up hoodieor lionized Steve Jobs for his streamlined Issey Miyaketurtleneck. Dress for the job you want, the old adage goes. “Desk jobs and hospitality uniforms perform a symbolic function to both standardize bodies and project an image of unity and authority,” says Tynan. “Uniforms are part of a symbolic system that gives institutions or companies a lot of power over workers' bodies and a hand in styling the service encounter.” As something of an RTO influencer, Xander Maddox has taken advantage of this fuzzy workplace style moment. OnInstagramandTikTok, he shows off his daily outfits for his job in digital finance. He started posting his office looks around 2023 and, once or twice, his content has gone viral. Maddox subscribes to a new idea of an office uniform, far from the days when suits and ties were standard issue. He describes his style as “elevated but cozy,” and prefers looser, relaxed silhouettes. He loves labels like Fear of God, The Row, Lemaire, and Our Legacy, though he often approximates the look of those brands with more affordable pieces fromCOSorUniqlo. His standard work uniform comprises a loosepleated trouser, anoversized T-shirt—sometimes with ahoodieover it—andloafers. This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. Maddox notes that he regularly receives compliments from coworkers, including his boss, but the most surreal moments are when people recognize him in public. “I’ve had a few people come up to me in person and tell me they like what I’m doing, which has been strange,” he says. According to data shared by Google Trends, the novelty of reentering the office in earnest may have some unforeseen consequences. “After seasons of casual comfort and minimalism, men are embracing a new era of dressing up, redefining the traditional office wardrobe,” says Sagal Mohammed, the editorial and creative lead at Google Shopping. “Predictability is out, and personal expression is in, which probably explains the trending interest inoffice bagsand the return of classic tailoring-inspired looks.” Take, for instance, the top five results for the “best men’s ____ for the office” over the past year in the USA: “backpack,” “premium denim,” “casual shoes,” “fragrance,” and “polo shirts.” Or the fact that searches for “casual work outfits” and “business casual outfits” are currently at an all-time high since the start of the pandemic. Or the number one search term, related to office-core: “business core aesthetic men.” Indeed,the suitappears primed for a workplace comeback, despite the fact that people have been declaring itdeadfor decades. Where some workers have sought to bring their athleisure-inflected WFH lives with them back to the office, others are finding new purpose and pleasure in dressing in the elegant tailored wear of yore. And expressing one’s personality through clothing doesn’t always have to mean taking big swings; sometimes small nods—a lapel pin here, a bold sock there—can speak the loudest. “With individuality now at the forefront of office fashion,” Mohammed says, “workplace attire is no longer simply functional but also a form of self-expression.” On that front, Goulet, the editorial manager, did mention something that recently piqued his interest in office dressing: Harris Dickinson’s wardrobe in the recent filmBabygirl.Indeed, as an office intern who starts a kinky affair with his company’s CEO, Dickinson’s wardrobe—boxy suits, oversizedbutton-downs,neckties—felt charmingly anachronistic. “I was like, That’s alook,” Goulet said, reflecting on the way that wearing a suit suddenly seems strangely rebellious. “Why don’t I wearthatto the office?”

title: I Spent a Week Wearing the Summer’s Splashiest Dive Watch
article_text: In June 1752, Benjamin Franklin was monitoring an afternoon storm. Franklin had gathered a kite with a long string and a key tied near the bottom end to prepare for this very moment. As the rain came down and the thunder crashed in the distance, Franklin walked out into the storm, set his kite loose, and captured a bolt of surging lightning—a shade of yellow that frankly would’ve looked feeble and powerless next to the electrifying hue on Zenith’s new Defy Revival Diver. This latest release is Zenith’s second Defy Revival Diver (DRD from here on out) to push the color spectrum to its breaking point.While last year’s version paired a stainless steel case with screeching orange accents, Zenith managed to go bolder for the sequel. The neon yellow is even louder, especially set against the watch’s matte black case and bracelet—both made from light titanium. The orange in the 2024 edition was inspired by the original DND produced by Zenith in 1969. But there’s no historical precedent for the splashy yellow accents and matte black case used here; the pairing brings the archival model fully into the present. The watch looks like a supercar you’d customize in aNeed for Speedvideo game. Even if there isn’t an exact analog in the archives, the vibrant color is backed by historical utility. If you were heading below the depths for a scuba session in the ’60s, you would have wanted a watch that was as bright and luminescent as possible to ensure its legibility underwater. That’s why, for instance, the diving specialists at Doxa pump out their heavy-duty watches in a rainbow of deliciously fun colors, or why Bulova’s iconic “Devil Diver” comes in traffic-cone orange. Zenith’s new DRD can still dive—to the very precise 600 meters, which in feet just so happens to be 1,969, a nod to the year the Defy line was born. Nice touch. The new DRD continues a searing hot streak for Zenith, which has quietly put together a 2025 I’d stack up with any other watch brand. The brand began the year by launching a spin on its flagship Chronomaster with a gem-set rainbow bezel, and it hasn’t stopped putting out banger pieces since. At Watches and Wonders, I absolutely loved the revival of its elegant G.F.J. model that combined shades of blue and lapis lazuli. The brand has used the gemstone effectively all year: In May, it released a versionof the Chronomaster with a lapis lazuli dial. Now, thanks to this latest DRD, there are officially an abundance of Zeniths I’d love to add to my personal collection. I recently got to spend a solid week and change with the Defy Revival Diver on my wrist—and there was a lot to love about the experience. What I loved Looking down at the yellow bezel, hands, and outer track on the dial feels like walking out of a dark movie theater into the afternoon sun. As someone who just wrote about the importance of keeping a summer watch in the rotation, I have an even greater appreciation for how this DRD could fit into my (or your) life. On sunny days, why not wear a watch brighter than a combustible star? The watch's exhibition caseback What else did I love? With both this reference and last year’s, I appreciate that Zenith remained faithful to many of the details from the original 1969 release. The 37 mm size stays true to the era, and the small size makes the watch feel even lighter on the wrist. The “ladder” bracelet follows the original design by Gay Frères—the most legendary bracelet maker in the industry, so good that Rolex purchased the company in 1998. The last vintage touch I really appreciate: the “automatic” type in twee lowercase cursive on the dial, which makes me scrunch up my face like I’ve just seen an adorable kitten. What I would do differently The matte black titanium is a cool idea, but I don’t think it’s a great match with this high-voltage shade of yellow. Zenith was going for a high contrast between the neon and sheenless case and bracelet, but the chasm between the two doesn’t play right for me. The matte finish makes the case look more like a dull gray than black to me. The vivid yellow only makes it apparent how lifeless the matte elements appear. What’s more painful is that you get a taste of what the watch could’ve looked like with a shiny black exterior. The dial pairs these two elements perfectly and helps me understandwhat compelled Wiz Khalifa to pen an anthem about this color combination. If I had a choice between this new DRD and last year’s orange-and-steel version, I would lean toward the latter. All in all, my enthusiasm for the new DRD was closer to the electric yellow shade than the dim matte black case. Earlier this year,I wrote about how watch brands are trying to maximize the fun in high-end watchmaking. This new diver is right in line with that idea: a super-light watch that can explore 600 meters underwater, featuring a shade of yellow that will be a surefire hit at any summer shindig. When last year’s orange Defy Revival Diver arrived, it never occurred to me it needed a sequel. However, this second version is making me greedy for a whole rainbow of DRDs. The vintage-inspired watch is the perfect template for Zenith to experiment with color, and I hope I’m trying on cotton-candy pink,Bratgreen, and Jolly Rancher blue versions of the model in the coming years. The specs Titanium case and bracelet, 37 millimeters, water resistance to 600 meters, 60-hour power reserve, date function between 4 and 5 o’clock, automatic movement, exhibition caseback, $8,200.Buy it here.

title: Here Is Everything Timothée Chalamet Has Ever Worn to a Knicks Game
article_text: As the 2025New York Knickswaded through athrillingly unchartered, if ultimately ill-fated, NBA postseason, the surest bet you could place in advance of any game was that Timothée Chalamet would be there: sitting courtside, hyping up his beloved team, and wearing some sort of charmingly slovenly ensemble. The actor and native Manhattanite, whose childhood apartment in Hell’s Kitchen was approximately a 15-minute walk from Madison Square Garden, went out of his way to attend the team’s playoff games this season, carving out time in his busy Hollywood schedule to jet between various metropolises and small-market arenas. This love is serious: Hewent to Detroitto cheer on the Knicks. Heskipped the Met Galatowatch the game on an iPad. Hell, he even had his“born-and-raised LA baddie”girlfriend,Kylie Jenner, cheering on his home team—in Indianapolis, no less. Timmy Tim and Spike, ’til the very end. And for as long as Timmy’s been famous enough to sit (and be photographed) amongst the VIPs in the Garden’s Celebrity Row, he’s steadily built up his blue-and-orange wardrobe. Though the actor’s beenbing-bongingsince long before he was rubbing elbows with fellow Knicks fanatics like Ben Stiller and Spike Lee, he only recently started really dressing like a high-profile superfan. Luckily for us, the internet has photo documentation of every Knicks game Chalamet has attended in the last seven-ish years. Let’s review, shall we? Nothing gold can stay, but blue and orange are forever. The custom Chrome Hearts continues. Do we think Timmy went thrifting during his sojourn in Indianapolis? I feel like he’d cleanupin a Midwestern Goodwill. A private jet to Indianapolis,a suitcase full of Chrome Hearts, and a dream… If you ever needed a reason to justify owning a pair of orange cargo pants, this Knicks playoff run is it. TC’s customized Chrome Hearts Timberland boots have become his new courtside talisman. Whether or not they will bring good or bad luck remains to be seen. ¡Nueva Yooooork! Sitting alongside Bad Bunny at Game 6, Chalamet wore a customChrome Heartsvelour tracksuit (likely thing for him to do) with a striped polo shirt and matching Chromed-up Timbs. The moment Timmy postedthose filthy Timbson the ’gram, we knew what was going down. While Timmy’s girlfriend,Kylie Jenner, and her sister, Kendall, both opted for the standard courtside-baddie uniform (tank top, leather pants, strappy sandals), Chalamet followed a failsafe mantra of the diehead New York sports fan:Clear eyes, cooked Timbs, can’t lose.That, and he managed to dig up a pretty sickvintage Knicks teefrom the ’95 playoffs. 🎶Ricksout for the Knicks, Ricks out for the Knicks! 🎶 (The vintage Starter jacket is cool, too.) Per my more sports-mindedGQcolleagues, these performance-style hoodiesseem to be a bit divisive. But given that Chalamet went all the way to chilly Detroit to see the Knicks’ round-one matchup against the Pistons, it made sense that he’d bundle up a bit. This is a classic Timmy Tim post-swag mash-up of niche streetwear and wonky luxury wares: a Juun.J hoodie, camo-print jeans,Dior loafers, and a Knicks snapback. And lest we forget,that mustache. Who else is pairing a Raf Simons fall 1997 jacket with some track pants andUggs? Only Timmy Tim, that’s who! When Chalamet was in the depths of dressing for his bonkersA Complete Unknownpress tour—which also happened to coincide with this Knicks-Grizzlies game at MSG—he leaned heavily into 2000s nostalgia. This outfit has several aughts-era relics at play including anAlexander McQueen skull scarf(a grail amongst Kitson-patronizing socialites of yore), heavily whiskeredTrue Religion jeans, and a punchy Knicks leather bomber jacket. A Yankees hat at a Knicks game: What wouldMayor Eric Adamshave to say about this? A self-referential moment from Timmy here: the bookshelf-printed sweater is from the Japanese label Sacai’s fall 2023 collection, which pulled imagery from Christopher Nolan’s 2014 filmInterstellar, in which Chalamet appeared as the teenage son of Matthew McConaughey’s Cooper. (To reference another Nolan movie,Inception, there’s diegetic levels to this!) Also featuring what appears to be a fresh-from-the-box pair of Nike Field General sneakers. A kooky Burberry hoodie, yes, but also an Ivy Park face mask! Does theBeyhiveknow about this? Aside from the Isabel Marant sneakers, the real star of this outfit—aScarfaceparody tee featuring Stewie fromFamily Guy—washiding beneathTimmy’s Prada puffer. Fun fact: Timothée Chalamet’s mom, Nicole Flender, danced at Lincoln Center with the New York City Ballet as a child and later appeared on Broadway inA Chorus Line—hence, perhaps, this hat. Or, asBritishVogueput it at the time, the cap proved that the then-rising star was also “the pin-up for every aspiring actress” and “a heartbreaker for the modern era.” This game took place a little over a week after Chalamet’s first Oscars ceremony, when he was nominated for his breakthrough performance in Luca Guadagnino’sCall Me By Your Name. He was well on his way to becoming a big star at this point, which you can tell because of one extremely Hollywood accessory: a trucker hat from Brentwood Country Mart, LA’s finest purveyor of upmarket goods. Way back in 2017, not long afterCall Me By Your Namehit select theaters, Chalamet watched the Knicks courtside with two former classmates, Ansel Elgort and Violetta Komyshan, from Manhattan’s Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School, a.k.a. the school fromFame. At the time, Timmy had most recently beena student at NYU, and on this night, in a leather jacket, skinny jeans, and Dr. Martens, he really looked the part. More From GQ Connect ©2025Condé Nast.
