title: The Real-Life Diet of Reggie Bush, Who’s Still Doing Strength Training to Alleviate the Pain of 11 Years in the NFL
article_text: Reggie Bush is a superhero to an entire generation offootballfans. During his time at the University of Southern California—where he was one of the best college players ever, winning two national championships, earning All-American honors and aHeisman trophyduring a goated career—it was hard to imagine anyone could run faster than Bush. But now, at 40 years old, nine years removed from his last NFL game, Bush has in fact slowed down. After 11 years in the league, Bush has turned to a different sport to occupy his free time. TheSuper Bowl championis now an avid golfer, and he’s not shy about preaching the physical benefits of the game. And because he also wants everyone to look as fly as possible while they walk the fairway, Bush has collaborated with TravisMathew on the athleisure brand’s “A Legacy Reclaimed” line. As someone who likes to go into the store and buy an outfit straight off the mannequin, eliminating the often painstaking process of trying to put together a stylish golf fit with various pieces from around the retail floor, Bush is extremely hyped about the TravisMathew apparel he helped design, which includes a piece that combines two closet staples. “What's unique about this shirt, which has never been done before, it's agolfshirt with a hoodie on it,” Bush explains. “This is my design that I came up with and I'm very proud of it because I think it came out great.” When he’s not golfing, Bush is still a regular in the gym, but with a different purpose than when he was trying to avoid vicious linebackers. The lightning-quick running back is still running sprints and hitting leg day hard, but his strength training now is done to alleviate the pain of all those hits he used to take. Here Bush reveals the specifics of that workout, as well as the NFL teammate whose athleticism wowed him the most and the only beverage he keeps in his house. Reggie Bush: I'm in the Los Angeles area. Life for me now is a lot of involvement with my three kids. They're involved in every sport known to mankind. We're driving them to practice, going through homework, dinner, and bedtime. That's pretty much a nightly evening routine for us because we're very hands-on with our kids. We don't have nannies. We do everything with our kids, [though] do have really good help though from my in-laws. My wife's parents are amazing. They give us so much help. That's like our nannies if we had them. But a lot of my life is being a dad, being a husband, working on my own personal projects, and one of those is TravisMathew. Dad life and business life. I workout five days a week. Usually my day starts out with a workout. I have a number of injuries from playing that if I don't work out, that they'll catch up to me. It's important for me to keep my body strong, keep my body fit and healthy. Because I'm constantly working onstrengthening, that alleviates some pain for me in some areas. There was a time two, three years into retirement, where I was just in a lot of pain. When you lose that routine from playing in the NFL—when to wake up, when to go do all these different things—now all that is placed on your shoulders. It's a tough place to be for some people, because not everybody is able to keep it going when it's all on you. Thankfully, I've had great support at home with my wife and kids. My wife and I work out together all the time. We're actually about to work out together after this. I'll just run through it real quick. My second year in the NFL, I tore my PCL. That's the posterior cruciate ligament. That basically wraps around the back of your knee, and that is part of a couple different tendons and ligaments that keep the knee stable and strong. I tore that, and doctors advised me not to repair it, because they said I would heal quickly and get back faster on the field. I wish I never did that. But listening to NFL doctors, I didn't do surgery on it, so I actually don't have a PCL anymore in my left knee. Then the next year, my third year in the league, I tore my medial meniscus, which is on the interior portion of your knee. That led to microfracture surgery. Microfracture is very tough. For a lot of people, it is usually career ending. Basically what they do is drill holes in the bone—literally, with a drill! Because of wear and tear in that area, I had no cartilage in between my knees. The interior portion of my left knee was bone-on-bone, and that was year four in the NFL. I ended up playing 11 years. The doctors told me at that time I probably wouldn't play longer than another three years. We talk about it lightly and loosely, butcoming back from injury—especially the injury I came back from—is one of the toughest things that you can possibly do in your career. I still have pain from it. I still get swelling in my left knee from it. It still limits me in certain ways. But again, because I focused on strengthening and staying flexible and all these different things—and I wear orthotics as well—it helps with alleviating the pain, being able to walk, and still continuing some sports. Oh, man. It depends. What time of the year? What time of the day? Is it windy? But no, I work a lot on my golf game. I love the game of golf. It's giving me an opportunity to still be an athlete. When you leave professional sports, especially football, you retire young. I retired at 32 years old, and in pretty much every other form of business, that's impossible. Nobody retires that young. Right? You retire young, and you're still very athletic, and you still have this need to compete. Golf has given me that opportunity to still be an athlete, compete, work out. A lot of my workouts are geared towards golf and strengthening my legs and different things like that. My golf game is…I think it’s in a good place. I love to hit the driver. That's my favorite. Putting can always improve, but I feel like my iron play has improved a lot as well over these last years. I'm down to a four handicap. Actually, what's funny is that I didn't play golf when I was in the NFL. I didn't pick the golf clubs up until about year 10. About two years before I retired, I picked it up, fell in love with it, and a lot of my friends and teammates were playing golf. The camaraderie was there. The ability to still compete and talk trash and bet money and all these things were in the sport. That's why I fell in love with it. Yeah. Oh my god, man. My intro to the NFL was very unique because I was drafted to the New Orleans Saints five months afterHurricane Katrina. I got there at a period where there wasn't much there. The city was a ghost town. There were very few restaurants that were open, [but] a lot of fast food restaurants. I hate admitting this, but there was a Sonic very close to our facility. I was eating Sonic here and there. Then I ended up hiring a chef just because I didn't want to get stuck on fast food. New Orleans is known for its food. If you go visit, you know to leave your diet at the door, because all the food there is amazing, lots of flavors, lots of unhealthy ways it's prepared. We love to eat, and it is really good, but unhealthy long term. Obviously, because of everything they had been through—people hadn't come back yet, businesses hadn't come back yet—I actually became really close with my chef. But there were times where I was leaning on some of these fast food restaurants as well. The nutrition when I got into the NFL is nowhere what it is now. Now they have smoothie bars! They have nutritionists in these facilities now. We didn't have a nutritionist. We didn't have no smoothie bars. I think the knowledge of what nutrition athletes need has also improved significantly. Teams, owners, and GMs have started to see the connectivity between performance and the way we're eating. I'm not complaining at all about what I had, but I just went toNew Orleansat a very unique time. It's something that always sticks out in my mind, because I went down there at a time when the city was depleted, and they were looking for hope anywhere. We were able to step in as a team and help uplift those spirits by winning football games. It wasn't the solution to all the tragedy they had been through, but it was just a step in the right direction. I'm happy I went there because when I look back on my career, New Orleans was my favorite stop. One thing I think they need to getrid ofthat’s still out there and is still an issue is field turf. When we look at the studies and the correlation between field turf and ACLs, PCLs, meniscuses, just about all leg injuries, a lot of it is traced back to the surface that you play on. They're playing on one of the most dangerous surfaces. We don't see soccer being played on field turf! In Europe, they would never allow that. Right? For some reason here—especially the NFL, which is the most dangerous sport—you're playing on the most dangerous surface. The reason why it's dangerous is because athletes are now bigger, stronger, faster. It continues to evolve. When you're that strong and that fast, something's going to give. You plant your foot into that turf and what happens is turf will grab. Grass gives. If I plant my foot going full speed on grass, it's going to tear a little bit and give. If I'm that same athlete and I plant my foot on rubber, fake grass, and I plant my cleat full speed, it's going to grab. I'm going to be able to stop a lot harder, but my joints are going to suffer because of that. You see guys not even get touched [get a] torn ACL.Odell Beckham Jr.in the Super Bowl tore his ACL and pretty much ended his career. He hasn't really recovered since, but it's all from turf. Unfortunately, NFL owners still believe that turf is the cheapest, most cost-efficient way in a league that annualizes billions every year. It's not adding up to me. It's a repetitive cycle, and it's going to continue. It's unfortunate. It will continue until the players decide to stand up and say, “Listen, we don't want to play on turf anymore.” The thing is, all players hate it. Never ever again. No sports should ever be played on turf. I'm coaching my son's flag football team. I complain about the turf that we have to play on. My son was going for a touchdown, he got pushed, he landed and banged his head on the ground. Now he's lying on the ground, hurt. If that's grass, he's landing on something much softer. He’s nine years old and I’m mad about this! Imagine grown men who were 200-300 pounds playing this ultra-violent game on the worst turf. Players are scared at the end of the day. Whatever the players want, they can get. They hold the ultimate power, which is to just sit out. Unfortunately, that is the only way they will be able to have leverage in their negotiations with the Players' Association versus the NFL and their collective bargaining agreements. Two things: We don't have guaranteed contracts in the NFL, and we’re put on the worst surface. You're talking about a league where I can sign you for five years, 100 million. Something happens halfway into year one, and I don't like you? I can cut you. That’s a nightmare for most people. I can speak to the hyperbaric chamber, because we had a chiropractor that a lot of the guys used to go to in New Orleans, and they had [one]. I actually bought one as well. It's funny. I bought one and then never used it. It was just a waste of money. But I honestly don't know if it helped me at all or not. I slept in that thing. I would take naps in it at my chiropractor's house. I don't know, man. It’s just based on if you believe in it or not. Supposedly you're breathing the most pure oxygen, the most pure air, and your body's supposed to heal that much faster … meanwhile, I'm in pain every day. Waking up in pain, going to sleep in pain. I don't know if those hyperbaric chambers actually work, but they started showing up probably three years into my career. In college, we never used anything like that. It’s more of a tool to help you heal. It's not necessarily a performance tool to help you play better or run faster. I think to literally notice the effects you'd have to sleep in that thing seven days a week. I think you can definitely train yourself toget faster. Everybody has their limit. What's your potential? When kids ask me how to get faster I tell them to go run track. Track and field, in my opinion, is the way to learn how to run faster. It focuses on your hip flexors, hip flexibility, explosiveness, your running pattern, your running gait, speed, agility, all that. All three of my kids run track, and I've seen them get faster since they started. I didn't start until I got to high school. I wish I had run track when I was younger because I would've been even faster. If you can even imagine that. Right? When I ran track in high school, I started because I wanted to get faster for football, but then I fell in love with the competition side of it. The me versus you. Even the relays—I ran the 4x100 relay, 4x400 relay, and it's just about competition. I've always been drawn more to dual-sport athletes who can do football, basketball, baseball, track, golf, whatever it is. I think those are some of the most successful athletes. That's why all my kids play at least two to three sports. I think it just gives you a different perspective and different understanding. You learn things in these different sports that you can apply into whatever that final sport is that you end up choosing. There's a lot. That's what football is literally built on, guys like that. Even the guys you don’t know are built like action figures. But I'll give you one guy that I played with in Detroit.Calvin Johnson. 6"6', runs a 4.3, maybe even 4.2 [40-yard dash], can jump as high as LeBron James probably. He had the speed, the height, the hands. He had it all. I'll never forget one time we were in practice—I would always run extra sprints after practice just to be in great condition—and he and I were running sprints together. I'm usually always first, whoever I'm running with. On this particular day, I'm running as hard as I can. It physically looks like I'm running hard. He looks like he's just jogging, because he has that long stride, and he was still beating me! I couldn't believe it. I was like, this dude is arguably one of the greatest athletes to ever grace this field. Tall, long arms and built like a basketball player, but has the speed of a cheetah. You just don't see a lot of guys like that, especially playing receiver. He’s the only receiver that I can remember teams actually double teaming at the line.You can look up that video. Jerry Rice, some of the greatest receivers ever, nobody else got that treatment. [Matthew] Stafford would still throw the ball, and he would still catch it. I still love to run. I still love to sprint. I run on the treadmill. I'll start with some form of—we call themA skips and B skipsin track—but things to open up my hips. Most of my running is on the treadmill just, again, because I have some injuries to my left knee. I like to run at a slight incline, and that helps alleviate some of the pounding, the full force of my body weight on my knee. I run probably about anywhere from 12 to 15 sprints. They're all around one minute long. I'll go up to about 12 miles an hour, which is pretty fast on the treadmill. Then once I go from there, we'll do a round of core sit-ups. I usually will focus on my legs. I try to not lift heavy upper-body anymore because I just don't need it, and I've had some shoulder injuries. I actually have a tear in this shoulder right now. I just don't want to go get surgery, man. It's been lingering since I played, and I don't want to go back under the knife. Maybe at some point I'm going to have to, because it's just going to get to the point where I'm just not going to be able to take it. But it doesn't affect my golf swing right now! I'll do mostly core, lower body. I don't do back squats anymore. I try to take the pressure off my spine and focus more on elongating my spine. I have a herniated disk in my lower back that I just need to be mindful of. I do a lot of golf-specific turns, twists, stretches, swings. Golf is healthy for you, man, because if you treat it the right way and you treat your body the right way, it helps you to lengthen out, stretch your spine, strengthen your lower body, your core. It's been healthy for me because there’s things that I've been needing to work on to keep my body stable. That's what it's about for me now: stability, lower body strength, and strong-ass core. My wife handles all the cooking. She's a beast in the kitchen. She is amazing. I'm not just talking her up because she's my wife. She could write a cookbook. She could be a chef. A lot of the food that she cooks is amazing, amazing stuff. We really rely on my wife. I don't know where we would be in this house without my wife and her cooking. Exactly, probably still eating Sonic. I try to eat as healthy as possible, but here and there, I might throw in my annual In-N-Out Burger. But for the most part, I try to focus on healthy eating, [things like] avocado, fruits, eggs in the morning. I try to stay away from sugar, but it's a little hard just because a lot of things have sugar in them. One of the things that I'm most proud of is that I take vitamins every day.Every day. Multivitamins, vitamin D and vitamin K—those two go together—and other things that my body needs from a supplement standpoint just to keep me healthy and strong. Idrink a lot of water. We literally only have water in my refrigerator. That's my routine. I think the vitamins are ultra important, especially for me as I'm getting older. I want to make sure everything is functioning properly. I do focus on my health a lot. In-N-Out Burger, and probably ice cream. Those are my two weaknesses right now. InReal-Life Diet,athletes, celebrities, and other high performers talk about their diet, exercise routines, and pursuit of wellness. Keep in mind that what works for them might not necessarily be healthy for you.

title: Nike’s Hottest Air Force 1 of 2025 Is Here, Courtesy of 2 Legendary Streetwear Brands
article_text: Two-waysneakers collabsare old hat. Butthree-way collabs like the Supreme x Goodenough xNike Air Force 1? They’re a rarer beast. Dropping as part of the New York skate stalwart’s summer 2025 collection, these sneakers might just be one of the most unexpected grails of the year. Supreme x Goodenough x Nike Air Force 1 If Goodenough doesn’t ring a bell, it’s time to brush up on your streetwear history. Founded in 1990 byHiroshi Fujiwara, the godfather of Japanese streetwear, it’s a punk- and hip-hop-influenced imprint that’s known for its graphic tees and workwear-y menswear. After leaving Goodenough in the late ’90s, Fujiwara launched his Fragment Design project in 2003, going on to work on legendary projects with the likes ofAir Jordan,Moncler,Red Wing, and many more. Now, though, the designer’s OG label is making a long-awaited comeback through this new collab with Supreme. Taking on the classic‘Triple White’ Air Force 1, the sneaker mixes it up by adding leopard print Swooshes to the sidewalls.Supreme’s signature box logo lands on the right heel, while Goodenough's lowercase ‘g’ hits the left. Co-branding is printed on the tongue label and insole, and just in case there was any doubt, the semi-translucent outsole spells out “SUPOODENOUGH” underneath. As well as the Forces, the power duo have also worked on a massive range of apparel and accessories. We’re talking MA-1bombers, patchworkjackets,sweaters, button-downs, tees, and all manner of caps and hats. If you took a L on the last Supreme x Goodenough drop back in 2007, this might just be your lucky day. Supreme x Goodenough x Nike Air Force 1 The Supreme x Goodenough x Nike Air Force 1 is set to release exclusively at Supreme’s website and brick-and-mortar stores on June 5. A retail price has yet to be confirmed, but honestly? It’s theresaleprices that you should be worried about. This story originally appeared onBritish GQ.

title: The Ethical Assassin: One Man's Quest for the Perfect Way to Kill a Fish
article_text: The fish thatwould die from a spike through its brain in the shadow of an oil rig, 45 miles off the coast of Louisiana, and would be served, 22 days later, in the Grand Salon of the Japanese ambassador’s residence in Washington, DC, was about two-and-a-half years old when it made the worst dining decision of its short life. A chunk of barracuda, itself pulled from the water only an hour earlier, proved the fatal temptation. The fish was a yellowfin tuna, 75 pounds, 36 inches long, and pure muscle. Andrew Tsui, the man who caught it, has fished all his life and is in fine shape for a 46-year-old. The tuna nearly pulled his arms off. We had set out from Venice, Louisiana, into the waters that will eventually consume it, toward the fields of rigs that are at least partially to blame. Until nine days earlier, the body of water we were in had spent the previous 475 years uncontroversially called the Gulf of Mexico. Now, who knew? As if by common consent, none of the nine people pressed together on the 37-foot boat mentioned it. We had been assembled by Tsui, a DC lawyer who is also a roving evangelist for seafood in general, and the Japanese fish-slaughtering method known as ike jime in particular. Ike jime involves euthanizing, bleeding, and destroying the spinal column of a fish as quickly as possible. All morning we had drifted beneath the immense, eerie rigs, bombing across the water from one to the other. Each was a little different, as though they had been made from kindergartners’ drawings. One looked like it was built atop a canopy of forest, another like it was made out of Lego, another like a giant bouncy castle. A few were unmanned and emitted mournful siren blasts every 30 seconds, to warn away passing ships. On others we could see tiny men in hard hats, hundreds of feet in the air, going up and down stairways and in and out of steel doors. A few leaned on the rails, smoking and watching us bob below. They ignored it when we waved. Andrew Tsui on the Gulf in early February. Our two-man crew called the rigs by nicknames: Moxie, Who Dat, and so on. They were local boys, chosen by Tsui because they were cool with him performing ike jime on board, a very different practice from the traditional American custom of throwing fish on ice and letting them suffocate to death. “Charter captains can be persnickety,” Tsui said. “These can be million-dollar boats, with all kinds of liability issues. So I understand if they don’t want people fucking around with exotic shit. They want you to just whack it, throw it in the box, and move on.” At our first stop we caught the barracuda and a rainbow runner, a sleek little member of the jack family. But yellowfin was our goal; specifically, a small yellowfin. A few weeks earlier, Tsui had been asked by contacts at the Japanese Embassy to bring back something special for the emperor’s birthday celebration, at the end of February. Anything bigger than about 80 pounds—and yellowfin can get as large as 400—would be impossible to transport back to DC intact. It reminded me of Thanksgiving in Louisiana, when home cooks scour supermarket bins for turkeys small enough to deep-fry. Looking out at the vast waves around us, finding the perfect petite tuna seemed just as improbable. Then, beneath the rig called Tinker, Tsui’s line suddenly took off. The rod bent in half. Tsui grunted as he reeled, fighting for each turn, only to lose all his progress each time the tuna decided to run. We all leaned over the rail, staring into the water. “Color!” somebody finally yelled, as a flash of silver appeared, indicating the fight was close to over. The first mate, Kyle, reached for the gaff, a nasty-looking barbed hook on a pole, designed to take fish the final few feet into the boat. “Careful with that,” Tsui said. On a small and chaotic boat, a gaff is always dangerous, but he meant to be extra careful with this fish. Kyle nailed it, catching the tuna just behind the gills and swinging it onto the deck. The prize tuna that was served at the emperor’s birthday at the Japanese Embassy in February. Tsui took a moment to catch his breath and rest his arms. Then he followed the tuna to the back of the boat. The fish was shaped like a torpedo, sheathed in scales that went from cobalt blue along its head to a silver so shiny that it might have been made of aluminum. Painterly swaths of yellow ran along its sides, up the scimitar-shaped fins, and on the triangular spikes that studded its powerful tail. The oversized eye and open mouth gave it an expression of almost comic surprise. It was extraordinarily beautiful. Among the equipment Tsui had brought aboard was an oblong piece of foam, stained with splotches of dried blood. He called this “the futon.” He lay the futon on the deck and the tuna down upon it. With one hand pressing on the body to keep it still, he grasped a seven-inch spike in the other. He took a moment to locate a spot just above and behind the fish’s eye and plunged the spike into its hindbrain. The fish twisted once, its dorsal fin stiffened, and then it was still. Tsui cut deep slits behind each gill and placed it upside down in a bucket, allowing the residual ghost of the fish’s blood pressure to do much of the work of exsanguinating the body. Then he rummaged through a kit and selected a length of spooled wire; it had a light-blue float on one end, shaped like a Dungeons & Dragons die. There are two ways to perform shinkei jime, the step of ike jime that involves threading a wire into the neural canal in order to cut off further activity of the nervous system: You can go through the head or you can go through the tail. Tsui opted for the latter, making a deep cut beneath the tuna’s caudal fin. The revealed cross section resembled a spider, with the thin bands of the fish’s ribs forming delicate legs. At the center of the spider’s head, Tsui located a tiny hole into which he teased the wire, pushing it the length of the fish’s spine. Though brain dead, its body involuntarily twitched and flapped as Tsui sawed the wire back and forth. “The shimmy-shimmy shake,” one of the fishermen said. “The pickle tickle,” said another. Tsui kneeled at the side of the futon, cradling the fish almost tenderly until it stopped moving. Among other things, ike jime is about the management of energy. In literal terms, this includes rapidly shedding body heat, as the fish is ushered into death, but it inescapably echoes the way we talk about such forces asqi, orsoul.By the time Tsui slipped the tuna into the watery embrace of an ice slurry, perhaps 15 minutes had passed since the moment it left the water. We caught three more tuna that day, each dispatched in the same way. Back in Venice, Tsui found a Styrofoam container that miraculously fit the one he planned on delivering to Washington. He cut a notch in its tail, for ID purposes, and packed it in ice. He and some friends were staying in a house that loomed on stilts, 60 feet above the dock. The walls were covered with fish trophies, fish posters, and fish homilies. The couches were deep, leather, and reclining. Our party was possessed with the tired but giddy bonhomie that follows a day at sea; even if things have been perfectly calm, there’s an unspoken sense that you have together survived some elemental vulnerability. We drank tumblers filled to the top with Maker’s Mark and pebble ice. Tsui stood in the kitchen working on dinner, using the rest of the day’s catch. He travels with a set of Japanese knives and a kit of collapsible toiletry bottles filled with culinary staples: mirin, soy sauce, yuzu, sugar, extra-virgin olive oil, et cetera. From the rainbow runner he cut silky ribbons of sashimi. He reduced one of the other yellowfin to the perfect geometric rectangles of its dark pink loins, which he then cut into cubes for a bowl of poke. The photographer we were with reached over with chopsticks to grab a piece. “So, the idea is that the fish tastes better because of how it died?” she asked, closing her eyes with pleasure as she chewed. “Was killed,” Tsui interrupted. “I’m sorry?” “This fish didn’t die,” he said. “This fish was killed.” The answer tothe photographer’s first question was,Yes—the tuna tasted better. And the distinction that Tsui insisted on goes to the heart of his mission. In an immediate sense, that is to promote ike jime, which has been widely used for centuries in Japan, and for decades in countries that do meaningful business with Japan’s high-end seafood market. The practice has a remarkable effect on the quality of the meat, its shelf life, and, consequently, on its potential applications. The moment our tuna left the water, it experienced gravity for the first time. It saw its first unfiltered sunlight. The fiberglass deck of the boat may have been the first hard surface with which its body had ever made contact. In short, it had found itself in an environment so alien that it might as well have been shot into space. And, of course, it had been hooked through the mouth, endured a long battle, and was quickly running out of oxygen. By killing the fish quickly and then shutting down its nervous system, Tsui had arrested the effects of this massive stress, leaving the fish’s flesh free of blood, adrenaline, and other substances associated with a panicking animal. At the same time, he had drastically slowed the depletion of the energy molecules known as ATP and the rise in lactic acid that mark the onset of rigor mortis. “People think ike jime is some kind of Oriental magic trick,” Tsui says. In fact, its effects are quite quantifiable. Ike jime, says John Stieglitz, a research associate professor and the director of Sustainable Seafood Research and Development at the University of Miami, “results in distinct and significant biological differences compared to conventional harvesting methods.” These differences are quantifiable by such metrics as muscle pH, bacterial load, and bioelectrical impedance analysis (which gauges living or dead tissue’s electrical conductivity). All of these, plus others like shear force (tenderness) and K-factor (potassium content), have been commonly accepted as measures of meat quality for years but have rarely been applied to fish. Stieglitz and his team recently completed a study that measured the shelf life of yellowtail snapper killed conventionally versus via ike jime. The results are pending review and publication, but he says that ike jime extended the shelf life of the fish by as much as a week. For a fishing industry in deep crisis, the economic implications of that week—where the fish could be transported to and what it could be used for when it gets there—are potentially enormous. Likewise for restaurants working with razor-thin margins when it comes to waste. As the founder and head of the Ike Jime Federation, Tsui has been a Johnny Appleseed of brain spikes, traveling the country and preaching the gospel to fishermen, chefs, scientists, policymakers, journalists, and anybody else who will listen. But Tsui’s larger project is to address the entirety of Americans’ relationship to seafood, which can be generously summarized as neurotic. “We tend to eat fish very defensively,” Tsui says. “We’ve had generations of people who were traumatized by one bad experience with seafood and basically said, ‘Yeah, I don’t eat fish. I don’t like fish.’ What the fuck does that even mean?” Ask a food poisoning victim what the culprit was, and 9 times out of 10 they will say the fish, even if facts dictate that it’s just as likely to be the salad. At the heart of the problem, Tsui believes, is a deeper disconnect with the underwater world. The average toddler knows the names, behaviors, and uses of dozens of land animals. Meanwhile, fish and their world remain alien, uncanny, and homogeneous. “Everything in the ocean is either ‘a shark’ or ‘fish,’ ” he says. “We’re teaching our kids lions and giraffes and zebras before they learn anything about the sunfish in their backyards. You have this missing line of sight into the underwater world, and I would argue there are consequences for that.” It doesn’t take a lot to see what these might be. Americans are eating more seafood than they ever have, but despite the almost endless resources of three coasts, 80 percent of it is imported from overseas. What we do use at home is a tiny fraction of the available bounty. The Gulf is one of the most diverse fish habitats in the world and yet we largely use it for only a handful of fish species, such as red snapper, mahi mahi, flounder, tuna. These satisfy our narrow demand that fish perform as a meat stand-in, i.e., a big piece of protein on a plate; Tsui calls it the “prison of fillets.” Nor do we seem aware of the value of our seafood inheritance to others. The Gulf is home to over a dozen species of wild grouper, which—bluefin tuna’s PR notwithstanding—is among the most prized fish for millions across Asia. Yet few if any Gulf fishermen seem to be aware of that market’s existence and lack the infrastructure to supply it if they are. Meanwhile, farmed fish presents an entirely different set of environmental, labor, and health issues. To try to eat seafood can feel like a perfectly distilled version of the modern dilemma of how exactly one is supposed tobe—that is, how a thinking and feeling person might engage with the world while doing as little harm as possible but remaining attuned to such virtues as pleasure. If there’s one object reserved for Tsui’s strongest derision, it’s the tyranny of “fresh,” which, despite a recent fad for “dry-aged” fish, remains the seafood industry’s greatest fetish.Freshis to seafood whatsmoothis to whiskey—subjective, capricious, and ultimately a red herring. After all, we understand that time, if anything, improves many foods: cheese, pickled vegetables, beef, wine. “There are all these very arbitrary cultural designations,” he says. “You smell a piece of cheese and you think, Oh, that’sripe.I’m going to bite it. You get near some oysters that smell a little fucked up and you think, My God, they’re going to kill somebody. Whether it’s true or not doesn’t matter. What matters is cultural memory, imprinting, trauma, mythology.” Tsui grows impatient with those who complain that ike jime matters only to the high-end sushi bars and other rarefied corners of the culinary world. Instead, he says, ike jime should be seen as a “conceptual prism” through which we can view the entire seafood ecosystem: “What if I told you that quality is not the result ofrecency of deathbut rather ofmanner of death?” I first metTsui at a mutual friend’s house in New Orleans. He had just come from a trip to the Gulf where he’d been slow pitch jigging—a highly technical method of fishing that is currently in vogue. Slow pitch involves very light rods and lead lures optimized for specific depths rather than species, the result being that you never know quite what will emerge when you reel them in. That night, an enormous scamp grouper lolled in a coffin-size cooler, its eyes bulging from the pressure change on its journey from the deep. Tsui held court in the kitchen, barefoot, preparing other specimens from up and down the water column: lane snapper, American red snapper, blackfin tuna, and a spinycheek scorpion fish that he said he had never seen before but was 90 percent sure he could turn into sashimi without allowing the venom in its spikes to poison everybody present. (Fifty percent of the group declined those odds.) With thick hair and a square jaw, Tsui resembles an Asian Josh Brolin. In his day job, he is a partner in a major DC law firm, specializing in health care litigation. Before that, he spent over a decade as a lawyer for the Department of Health and Human Services, during which time he lost only two of the cases he took on. He lives in suburban Maryland with his wife and three young children. In addition to fishing, he has an eccentric assortment of obsessions: tennis, piano, raising rare goldfish, home-brewing the fermented Korean drink makgeolli. DC, somebody who lived there once told me, is full of this type: high-achieving strivers, without a bohemian bone in their bodies, who are nevertheless secret renegades and stone-cold weirdos. He grew up in North Carolina, a fisherman’s paradise, from the ocean on one end to mountain streams on the other, and innumerable ponds, lakes, and rivers in between. That’s where he got his first taste of fishing, puttering around University Lake, in Chapel Hill, with his father and his brother on Sunday mornings. Tsui’s parents were both UNC professors: He, a nuclear physicist from Hong Kong; she, a Chinese-American demographer raised in Hawaii. Tsui frequently compares fishing to a drug and he calls himself a junkie, neither in a way that suggests he’s being in any way glib. He remembers his first major dopamine hit, a largemouth bass he had no business catching, at about age five. “That fucked me up. From there it was all aboutHow do I catch that fish again?” He also remembers the first time he unintentionally caused a fish’s death. That was a sunnie that swallowed the hook and was permanently damaged in the process of extraction. That fucked him up too: “You throw that fish back in the water and watch it bob to the top, and it’s just a gut punch,” he says. For an Asian kid growing up in the South, fishing was a method of assimilation, like sports or church. Still, he found himself on the other side of a divide with his neighbors. “There’s a real catch-and-release culture in that community. It was almost taboo to bring fish home,” he says. Tsui’s family, on the other hand, ate what they caught whenever possible, a kind of return-on-investment for the time and energy spent on the lake. “We were not going fishing just for fun,” he says. “So, if the outcome of the fishing trip was a live animal, it was very hard for me to let that animal back in the water.” As an undergrad at Wesleyan University, Tsui founded a student fly-fishing club, not the most popular hobby among his progressive classmates. It forced him for the first time to think philosophically about the thing he loved. “I was challenged all the time: ‘Fucking redneck,’ or ‘You’re torturing fish.’ I needed some rejoinder to what felt like a character attack.” After graduation he moved to Hawaii, to live with his maternal grandmother and teach test-prep courses. For beer money he landed work on a commercial tuna boat. The captain turned out to be an ex-Marine named Lionel who had unusual methods. Whenever the crew caught a tuna, they were instructed to kill it immediately, using a wooden bat, bleed it out, and then perform shinkei jime with a monofilament wire. Lionel told them it was for the Japanese buyers at the tuna auction in Honolulu, who would pay more for fish treated this way. But there was more: He used the Hawaiian wordpono,which means a feeling of balance, harmony, and righteousness. “He said something to the effect of ‘If you don’t kill the fish, you can’t feel pono,’ ”Tsui says. When Lionel would give him fish to bring home, he could see the difference. The flesh was firmer when he cut it. There was no ‘fishy’ smell. It kept longer. He felt good eating it raw. For Tsui, it was a double revelation: Working with huge, warm-bodied fish, he was forced to consider for the first time what it meant to hunt and kill another living being. At the same time, he could see the intimate connection between how he chose to treat that animal and its value. “Before that, the value of fish for me was measured in vanity:Hold the fish out to the camera. Push it toward the camera so it looks bigger,” he says. “My eureka moment was when it came to me that the value of the fish is actually not about vanity, it’s measured indollars.It opened my eyes to the concept that some consideration for the welfare of the animal was a precondition of quality.” By the time Tsui headed back to the mainland, to study law at UNC, he had made an internal decision. No longer was he somebody who fished just for fun or for sport. “I said to myself: I am ameatfisherman.” Having spent time on a boat with Tsui, I can testify that he still speaks fluent sport fisherman; his native language may be Bro. But he is an expert code-switcher. When he is in persuasive mode, he speaks in a lawyer’s cadence—patient, careful, and in full sentences. He also has a poetic streak. To hear him expound on, say, the life cycle of Chesapeake Bay rockfish (known elsewhere as striped bass) is to simultaneously want to eat, catch, and hug that fish: how in summer they stress out in the bay’s warm, oxygen-deprived shallows, growing greenish and wan, but, come autumn, they gorge on peanut bunker until they have the shoulders of high school wrestlers. (“Not college wrestlers; those would be in the open water,” Tsui says.) By November, as he tells it, there is no better distilled expression of the Mid-Atlantic Seaboard. And yet, because it has only a local market and limited ability to travel, November rockfish doesn’t command a high price. “Let’s say a very enterprising chef in Chicago wants to tell the story for the first time of what American seafood is or could be. The opportunity to express fully a seasonal pattern of Maryland rockfish is not available to them, because it can’t get there. Which is strange because somehow, magically, fish from the market in Tokyo get there every day,” Tsui says. “What ike jime allows you do is to say,Fuck local.” Perhaps you’ve noticed the preponderance of ¯Ora King and Faroe Islands salmon on menus in recent years—the first a trademarked brand name for chinook salmon farmed in New Zealand, the second the same Atlantic salmon you find in your local Walmart but farmed on an archipelago in the middle of the North Atlantic. They have taken over the world in part because fish farmers in those countries employ “stunner-bleeders” to quickly kill and bleed each fish—in other words, a crude version of automated ike jime. Meanwhile, the start-up company Shinkei Systems is working on refining that process with a machine that uses computer vision (to his credit, its 26-year-old founder, Saif Khawaja, does not use the termAI) to more precisely locate the hindbrain on fish of varying sizes and species. The company has raised some $8 million. Seafood globalism bears its own set of ethical and environmental concerns, but ike jime can benefit local markets too. When chef Junya Yamasaki arrived in Los Angeles to open his restaurant Yess, he was shocked by the inability to source California seafood and by the wretched quality of what little he could get. Before opening he recruited and trained a small fleet of commercial fishermen who now sell him and others their ike jime killed catch for three times the price of other fish. The Chesapeake Bay Legacy Act, recently passed in Tsui’s home state of Maryland, allows certified sport fishermen who perform ike jime to sell directly to restaurants—perhaps incentivizing a whole generation of “meat fishermen.” All of this is part of the story Tsui tells, synthesizing nature, commerce, and policy. His lyricism extends to such thoroughly unsexy topics as the Administrative Procedure Act of 1946, the Supreme Court’s decision striking down the longstanding Chevron doctrine, public comment periods, and all the myriad other regulatory mechanics that, he persuasively argues, underpin the entirety of America as we have known it—a kind of qi of the body politic. Regulations, as Tsui describes them, are every bit as much an artistic expression of a society’s values, preoccupations, and prejudices as its poetry. Indeed, you couldn’t ask for a more pithy summation of our problems with seafood than the fact that, while it is monitored by the government forsafety,there is no standardized legal designation for itsquality.There is no seafood equivalent, say, for the USDA’s grading of beef into Prime, Choice, Select, and so on. Nor, outside of certain laboratory contexts, are there rules governing the treatment of fish, as there are for land animals. By certain legal standards, fish are not, in fact, defined asanimalsat all. In the Grand Salonof the Japanese ambassador’s residence, in northwest DC, our tuna sat on a long banquet table, one eye staring blankly in the direction of a Ryūshi Kawabata painting of a woman carrying firewood, titledSpring in the Ancient Capital Kyoto (No. 1).The fish had been curved into a C, as though in mid-fight. Its head and tail, with the telltale notch, were intact; the body between them had been transformed into gleaming pink stacks of sashimi. It had been a turbulent week inthisancient capital, as Elon Musk’s DOGE had swept through various agencies. “This town is on fire,” Tsui told me as we lined up to pass through security. You would not know it from the crowd gathered for the annual celebration of the emperor’s birthday, one of diplomatic Washington’s most coveted invitations. Elaine Chao, the former secretary of labor and Mitch McConnell’s wife, chatted with the ambassador. There were blue-suited EU economist types; cadaverous spooks in bow ties; a selection of medal- and ribbon-wearing military from at least four continents, including one Estonian general who stalked through the room with wild eyes and a braided white beard. I spared a thought for our fish, ending up in this of all possible worlds. Tsui started working informally with the Japanese Embassy after bringing a high-level staffer a grouper several years ago. A few days later, a dinner invite arrived. “You don’t understand what you have here,” the official told him, over five different grouper preparations. “This is fish diplomacy.” We waited in line to try the tuna. It had been 22 days since our foray to the oil rigs, just enough to give it a rich mineral tang. In his welcome speech, the ambassador drew attention to two items among the lavish spread: Wagyu beef and ike jime tuna. “I have to admit, that kind of turned me on,” Tsui whispered. After the reception, we took a car downtown to the Old Ebbitt Grill, the clubby institution located across the street from the White House. The place was packed, the volume loud, the mood rowdy, ruddy, and triumphant. Here, within a short drive of the Chesapeake Bay, home to more than 500 species of fish and shellfish, cradle of 80 percent of the striped bass in the Atlantic Ocean, the only fish on the menu were farmed trout and Faroe Islands salmon. If nothing else, it was a profoundly boring selection. Over the weeks I’d spent talking to Tsui, something had been conspicuously missing. Ike jime is self-evidently a more humane method of killing than suffocation; anybody who has heard the sickening thunk of a fish slowly expiring out of sight in a cooler knows this intuitively. Of all Tsui’s arguments, though, this is one he rarely makes, because the people that he most needs to convince of ike jime’s virtues—what he calls “the hook-and-bullet community”—are not especially receptive to it. Fish welfare is neither quantifiable nor a winning argument. “Value-added” might be. Still, at the heart of ike jime lies death. I asked Tsui how many fish he thought he had killed in his life. He looked momentarily stricken and then mouthed, silently:A lot. He was quiet for a few moments. “I don’t know if I still feel pono when I’m killing a fish,” he said, finally. “There’s something very humiliating about not only killing a fish but exercising that much dominion over it.” Humiliating? “The power I have…it can be soprofane.The ability to exercise so much control over life. To effectively hack a nervous system? It’s obscene,” he said. “Does it just go unchecked? Am I not accountable to anything? Did I need to do it? Was Istarvingon that boat? I was actually quite overweight. So, again, it’s humiliating.” For a moment I entertain the notion that the entire enterprise has been an act of penance for five-year-old Andrew Tsui watching a sunnie, pulled inside out by his hook, bobbing sadly away on University Lake—an elaborate post hoc attempt to reconcile his guilt with the enduring monkey on his back. “This is arguably psychotic and self-aggrandizing, but I feel like the way I kill things is justified because I’m trying to influence the next generation—if I can just give them enough context and enough training,” he said. “I do feel strongly that when you extract a living thing out of the water, you have choices. The first fork in the road is: Do you want to harvest, or do you want to let it go and move on with your day? That first fork in the road gives you an off-ramp, spiritually or morally. If you say,I will keep this fish,you lose that off-ramp. But you can actually create anewoff-ramp by saying,I will try my best to minimize unnecessary stress. I can’t promise there will be no stress. But I will do my damndest.And the really exciting aspect of ike jime is that if you elect for that off-ramp and actively kill—if you exercise a little consideration and energy and thought and care—you create a symmetry in the product. You have actually created a superior product.” He gave a small laugh and asked that I stipulate for the record that he was now a little tipsy. He kept coming back to the legal doctrine of mens rea, he said—the “guilty mind” or evil intention that determines criminal liability. “But that’s like the fox guarding the henhouse,” he said. “It’s extremely subjective. Does the fish think I’ve got mens rea? I think we know the answer to that question.” The waitress came and we ordered hamburgers. Brett Martinis a GQ correspondent. A version of this story originally appeared in the June/July 2025 issue of GQ with the title “The Ethical Assassin”

title: How Haim Quit Caring About All That
article_text: Walking around California’sSan Fernando Valley with the Haim sisters is like touring Compton withKendrick Lamar, or New Jersey withBruce Springsteen. Danielle, Este, and Alana Haim arethemusicians from “the Valley,” and its yellow-hued streets have been the backdrop of their work for their whole career. (“They’re the San Fernando Valley’s house band,” says the director Paul Thomas Anderson, one of their closest collaborators and a fellow Valley native.) So, they’re kinda big dogs around here. Case in point: mooching around a vintage store that Este used to work at called Wasteland, they run into someone they know. “I’m seeing a bunch of stuff online,” their friend says, referring to the barrage of new-album promo flowing out of their social feeds lately, “and I’m like… the girls are back!” In the Valley with Haim, you’re only ever a brisk walk from a core memory. On this overcast day in March, as we stand outside a kitschy bowling alley where they used to go to birthday parties as kids, Alana gestures both ways down Ventura Boulevard, the “main artery” of the area, as she calls it. There’s the dry cleaners where Anderson shot their new album cover. It’s not too far from their mom’s old office. Oh, and a little further there used to be a diner they would go to after some of their first ever gigs. (It’s now a Sephora. “I don’t like to talk about it,” says Alana of this particular act of gentrification). “Paul is that way,” she says, talking, of course, about the aforementionedPTA, who grew up in the Valley and has spent large swathes of his life in cinema depicting its dusty charm. This is exactly the kind of thing you’d expect Alana Haim to say—she’s made two movies with him in the last four years, on top of everything else—but it feels no less electric to casually name-drop one of the greatest directors of all time, who also happens to be a close personal friend. The Valley, man. From left. On Este: Overalls by Courrèges. On Alana: Coat by Mimchik. On Danielle: Top by DKNY. In the Valley with Haim, nothing can throw you off your— Suddenly, a car pulls out in front of the sisters, who are walking in a line like they do in all their music videos (as Alana had told me earlier, “We’rereallyfucking good at walking”). “Sorry, we’re walking, sorry!” she says now to the driver, aware that she was a whisker away from making the news: “I get killed in the Valley… What a way to go!” We’re on course for the alley where they shot part of the “Summer Girl” video—you know, the one where they gradually shed layers and layers of clothes. “The last shot of the video is us walking right here,” Alana says, stopping outside a Barnes & Noble that sits under a retro cinema marquee. “Haim lore!” Haim is showing me around the Valley not just because they love it—though they doloveit—but because the nostalgia we’re tapping into by roaming these streets inspired parts of their upcoming fourth album,I Quit. For example, the Valley is responsible for this spit-take of a lyric, on a very autobiographical song about their high-school days called “Take Me Back:” “Molly took a shit in the back of the truck, didn’t even notice, she was too coked up.” “That really happened,” Este says. (They did, however, change the name to protect the privacy of this former schoolmate of theirs.) Written and recorded over the last three years,I Quitwas born out of a newfound self-assuredness that set in around the 10th anniversary of their 2013 debutDays Are Gone. “I feel like sometimes you cringe at [old] songs, but with that album I still hold it and I’m so proud of it,” says Alana. “I could look back at every single one of our albums and go, Fuck, so many people were like ‘Don’t do that’, ‘Don’t do that’, and we always stuck to our guns,” Alana says. “Now we’re just like, ‘Fuck off. If you’re not gonna believe in us, we can believe in ourselves. Fuck off!’” Over the course of a day together, it becomes clear that there are a handful of targets for thatfuck off: the rock music old guard that has patronized them for much of their career, the misogynists that question their musical abilities, and, yes, their exes (more on that later). No, it’s not a coincidence that it’s mostly men. But it’s not as angsty as that sounds—I Quitis about a sense of release, or an “exhale,” as Danielle refers to it. It’s the post-quitting high, rather than relitigating the shit that led to the quitting. The greatest indicator of this feeling is a sample of George Michael’s “Freedom! ’90” on the first track “Gone,” which is just about peak Haim—joyous, knowingly corny, weirdly moving all in one. “We never wanted [the title] to be a negative,” Alana says. “When we say ‘I quit’, it’s like, ‘I quit the things that don’t serve me.’ And it’s really amazing, ’cause quitting is a new beginning.” “The exit is also the entrance,” Este says. “I think now, after [making music] for almost 20 years,” says Danielle, “it finally feels like we can be like, ‘You know what, I don’t give a fuck what that person said about us…’” Este nods. “I’m done giving a fuck.” From left. On Alana: Top by Stella McCartney. Skirt by Dolce & Gabbana. On Este: Coat by Dolce & Gabbana. Briefs by Araks. Shoes by Stella McCartney. On Danielle: Jacket by Stella McCartney. Bra by Araks. Skirt by Co. We meet forbreakfast in the kind of Italian restaurant you can imagineTony Sopranodestroying some ziti at, which Alana (33, youngest Haim, guitar, keys and backing vocals) attends so frequently that, when asked what’s good, she basically recites the entire menu. On the journey here, I listened toI Quitin the way God and the band likely intended: riding up Santa Monica Boulevard in an Uber with the windows down, the tang ofLAexhaust fumes filtering into my lungs. In the weeks leading up to our meeting, a question had been haunting me: are Haim the most underestimated rock band in the world? It sounds kind of absurd considering the success they’ve had, but then you sit with their discography: a debut that arrived eerily perfect—maybetoopolished?—complete with five singles that each sounded like number-one records plucked from the 1970s. And four years later their second album,Something to Tell You, quietly built upon that sound, adding in layers of complexity… And then! In 2020, their masterpieceWomen in Music, Pt III, an album that stripped any remaining veneer from their production and their lyricism, revealing their raw core—songs about depression and grief and dealing with life-threatening illnesses, all the while maintaining their essential lightness. Throughout all of this, they’ve remained one of the most exhilarating live acts around. Don’t just take it from me, take it from actual Stevie Nicks: “It starts with Danielle’s voice—it is just stunning,” Nicks tells me. “She’s the first part of the puzzle, but then the percussion that Este and Alana wrap around her turn all of their songs into percussive masterpieces. [They are] something that I have never heard before. But coming from Mick Fleetwood’s great love of their kind of percussion, for me in a way, it’s like coming home. They could certainly all have been in Fleetwood Mac.” (Nicks adds that she’s working on a song with Haim, and that “some day, when you tumble into this song, you will understand everything I have just told you.”) In 2025, when a music festival grasps for a rock headliner that isn’t largely made up of octogenarians, the world offersGreen Daywith a shrug. No one seems to be able to agree on what mainstream rock is any more, which has led to the misappropriation of some great acts—people wantFontaines DCto sand down their punky edges! They wantThe 1975to stop singing about incels and wanking and start singing about something, I don’t know, normal! In Haim’s case, most people seem to want to shove them into the box labeled “pop”—it has been happening their whole career. “If we use one synth or one poppy thing they’re like, ‘They’re a pop band,’” Alana says. “And we’re like, pop isn’t a bad fucking word. Rock isn’t a bad word either.” What seems clear from their new album, however, is that they’re choosing to shake all of that stuff off and move on with their lives. It’s a great album that features more big swings than the kaleidoscopicWomen in Music, Pt III. There are tinges of country rock (on “Blood on the Street”) and dance pop (on “Spinning”, the first Haim songAlanahas been the sole lead on, and Este’s “Cry”). Haim have defied genre before, but onI Quit, they sound even less encumbered by their audience’s expectations. “With this album especially there was a lot of experimentation,” Alana says. “And it felt like we had the stage to actually experiment without feeling pressure about it.” The album came after a period of change for the three band members. Having returned from a euphoric post-pandemic tour, they found themselves all single again at the same time, with Danielle (36, middle Haim, lead vocals, drums, guitar) having split up with the band’s longtime co-producer Ariel Rechtshaid in early 2022 after nine years together. (I Quitis their first album without Rechtshaid, who does however have a co-writing credit on “Relationships,” which the band first started working on in 2017.) “All of our songs are about our collective trauma and going through it,” Alana says. “A lot of our last album was us grappling with going to therapy for the first time and these emotions that had been bottled up for so many years, and I think with this album, we’ve done the work on ourselves, and now it’s time to party.” It’s this stage of their lives that Danielle sings about on “Relationships”, the summery, post-break-up catharsis anthem—time in which they were drifting in and out of flings, though Este (39, eldest Haim, bass guitar, backing vocals) would meet her now-fiancé after not too long. “I’ve been single for the last three years,” Danielle says. “It’s been so fun.” And it does sound fun: after the break-up, Danielle moved into Alana’s house. To give you an insight into the vibe: “I have a beer fridge,” Alana says. “I’m like a frat boy trapped in a girl’s body.” During this time, she says, “My house turned into fuckin’Animal House. Growing up, we were not the cool house. We didn’t have good snacks. My therapist calls it ‘a corrective experience’. So it was like, at my house, it’s gonna beragers…” The weekly house parties were all well and good—until, one weekend, Danielle was ill. “Alana was like, ‘I think I’m gonna have a few people over,’” says Danielle. “I was like, ‘Just shut your room,’” says Alana. “Literally, like smelling the cigarettes…” says Danielle. “Danielle was like, ‘Can you guys stop smoking inside?’” Alana says. “I put an air purifier in her room. I think we partied ’til five in the morning.” “And I was like, ‘What the fuck…’” Danielle says. “Danielle moved out,” says Alana. And that was pretty much the end of that. From left. On Danielle: Cardigan and skirt by Vivienne Westwood. On Alana: Top by Vivienne Westwood. Shorts by Blumarine. On Este: Dress by Ferragamo. Shoes by Aeyde. Haim lore: itwas the Valley that forged Haim’s bond with Paul Thomas Anderson. PTA has lived in the Valley all his life – his last film,Licorice Pizza, was named after a record shop five minutes further down the road from the bowling alley we’ll head to later, and starred Alana Haim in her first role. “PTA is basically our fourth member,” Alana says. Since 2017, Anderson has made 10 (ten!) music videos with the band, most of which were shot “guerrilla-style” in or around Ventura Boulevard. When it came time to figure out the tracklist forI Quit, they tapped him up for that, too. “He was basically our A&R – ‘Don’t put this song on, put this song track two, put this song track five,’” Alana says. “We trust his taste so much.” They also asked if he’d want to shoot the music videos. There was just one small problem. “He was like, ‘You guys, I have a job!’” Alana says. “‘I’m a director, and I have my own movie. I can’t just drop everything for you.’” (Anderson is currently in post-production onOne Battle After Another, in which Alana once again features.) Nonetheless, PTA found the time to conceptualize and photograph the album cover, which was shot in a dry cleaner’s just a few minutes down the road from where the Haims grew up. “He always finds inspiration in just walking around,” says Alana. “There’s always time [to collaborate with Haim],” Anderson says over email, when asked how being the “fourth Haim” fits in around his actual job. “Mostly it just seems to work until it’s clear we all need to be in the same space together and then someone calls ‘roommate meeting’ and we get together and figure it out. We seem to be in a nice natural cycle of collaboration. It’s not going anywhere, if that makes sense. We’re stuck together.” Alana’s starring role inLicorice Pizzafelt, from an outside perspective, as though it could have been a fracturing point for the band. In classic Haim fashion, they poked fun at the tension in a TikTok during the making ofI Quit, Danielle and Este dragging Alana through a doorway kicking and screaming. The caption reads: “when your sisters are making you get back in the studio but you were born to be anOscaraward winning actress.” But even though it kicked off a healthy side hustle for Alana—she’s shot a couple of indies withRobert Pattinson,Zendaya, andJosh O’Connor—nothing much changed, and acting work has chugged alongside the album creation process. “It’s funny,” she says, “you go through your whole life and you think you’re gonna do one thing, and then you take a left turn and you learn new things. It opens up a new chapter.” Her sisters have other plates spinning, too: Este has been working in film and TV, co-composing the score for the Glen Powell x Sydney Sweeney romcomAnyone But Youand Margaret Qualley’sMaid, and managed to swing two months in Sicily to help with on-camera music scenes inThe White Lotusseason two. “I got to live at the hotel,” Este says, relishing it. Danielle has dabbled in collaborating with other artists, most recently featuring on a beautiful track on Bon Iver’s latest albumSable, Fable. That link-up then led to Justin Vernon writing onI Quit’s “Everybody’s Trying to Figure Me Out”. “He’s so talented,” Danielle says. “A super-genius.” “We all kind of let each other do whatever we want,” is how Alana puts it. Haim is so good at TikTok that they actually have their label asking them to help with social media strategies for other artists. “We’ll get calls being like, ‘We showed your TikTok in the Monday meeting,’” Alana says, “‘because we told all of our people that are helping A&R other bands how to TikTok.’ And I’m like, ‘Don’t…’” “Let people live!” says Este. “I wish the label would fucking do anything,” says Alana. “Like, marketing-wise. No shade to our label. I don’t wanna shade anybody. And then they ask us howwedid it. And I’m like, I don’t fucking know.” Does your label talk to you about algorithms? “I don’t care,” says Este. “I wish people would tell us what to do to get on...” Danielle trails off. “In our experience, no one can tell us how to do anything.” On social media, Haim is a record label’s dream—naturally funny, authentically themselves. “We’ve been performing as a trio and doing shows in our back yard since we were kids,” says Este. “Este would do physical comedy to make me laugh as a baby,” Alana explains. “She would, like, trip and fall and I would laugh, and that was just our whole lives. Being on TikTok is just an extension of that. It comes naturally. And like, why not?” During their childhood they were obsessed withSaturday Night Live, and looked up to cast members like Cheri Oteri, Molly Shannon and Maya Rudolph. “We look at every TikTok as anSNLsketch—how do you make people laugh in 30 seconds?” Alana says. That they’re unafraid to be goofy is a key part of the band’s charm. We talk about a viral clip of them performing the dance from their “I Know Alone” video live on stage. It’s an endearingly unserious—but not simple—dance, with lots of arm-swinging and knee-wiggling. Alana believes that some people miss that they’re taking the piss more often than not. “That’s where it gets lost in the sauce with people,” she says. “Even though we’re a rock band, we love movement,” says Danielle. “Prince danced,” says Este. “I mean, Talking Heads—movement,” says Alana. I sense this is a conversation they’ve had before, or at least it’s something that has bothered them before now. “It’s such an important part for us,” Danielle says, “I don’t know if the rock community…” “Takes that as a weakness,” Alana says. “I don’t know why.” The rock community has loomed as a spectre of disapproval throughout the past decade-and-change of their career. The beef has taken different shapes and sizes—one day it’s Portishead’s Geoff Barrow talking shit about them on Twitter (he only stopped after a 21-year-old Alana, who calls herself “the bulldog” of the family, confronted him about it at a music festival). The next it’s commenters under their live performance videos—“It’s always a guy,” Este says—who say that they’re not playing live because their guitars are not plugged in. “It’s like, my dog, we’re playing withwireless,” says Danielle. “Are you a fucking idiot?” These are the men—and yes, it is largely men—to whom they’re sayingfuck off, we don’t need your approvalonI Quit. And another thing… Did you know that Haim have never had commercial radio success in the United States? It’s a matter that understandably confounds them to this day. “We’re so lucky that we have incredible fans that have always supported us—like, we’ve never needed radio,” says Alana. “Alternative fucking rock fucking radio… You can tell how much I fucking love them.” “For some reason, people that need to put people in boxes don’t get us,” says Danielle. “It goes back to what we said,” says Alana. “We love to dance and we love to make people laugh, and for some reason that’s a no-go.” “I think it’s all quite antiquated,” says Este. “The whole setup is... who gives a shit about that? It’s really old school. We quit caring about that shit.” From left. On Danielle: Jacket by Isabel Marant. Bra by Louis Vuitton. Briefs by Araks. On Alana: Jacket and shoes by Louis Vuitton. Skirt by Dolce & Gabbana. On Este: Jacket by Ludovic de Saint Sernin. Skirt by Louis Vuitton. “Oh– !” “–Oh!” “–Aaaawww.” This is the sound of Danielle, Alana and Este Haim watching me bowl—hopeful encouragement followed by disappointment as the ball veers into the gutter. We’re in Pinz, a bowling alley that Alana still comes to often. Above the lanes is a photoshopped background of LA landmarks: Dodger Stadium, the Hollywood Bowl. There is a black and white photo of a kangaroo holding a bowling ball (his form isn’t great) by the toilets, which are labelled “Menz” and “Womenz”. “I don’t wanna say I’m good,” Danielle says as she picks out her ball. “I think I’m OK.” The pins clatter as she narrowly misses out on a strike. We clink our bottles and get talking about the dating nightmares that Haim have been sharing on TikTok in the weeks around the release of “Relationships”, like the time Alana flew from LA to London to meet a guy for New Year’s Eve, only for him to high-five her at midnight. As it turns out, the reality was way worse than how she originally described it. “I was 20, and I was so in love with this guy in a band,” Alana says. “Everyone thinks it’s about another guy and it’s not him, that theory is wrong.” She believed that they had been seeing each other exclusively for a year. Her sisters told her not to, but she flew out the week before New Year’s anyway to be with him. “And then he ghosted me the whole week,” she says.“And then I found out he was cheating on me with his ex… I was devastated. Devastated!” Este, too, has left some horror stories on the cutting-room floor. “I had a guy break up with me because I said that there was a possibility that our kid would have diabetes,” she tells me. (Este herself has Type 1). “He was like, ‘Then why are we here?’ And I was like, ‘What?!’” Danielle had shared on TikTok that, at 19, a music bro ex had discouraged her from making the kind of music that got Haim signed because he “didn’t get” it. She says that people have been reaching out to her, sharing their own experiences with similarly shady dudes. “I think it’s like a universal experience,” she says. “A lot of girls are being like, ‘Girl, I feel you.’ Just like, boyfriends not being supportive... But I think it’s kind of a popular theme.” Alana knows where she’s coming from. “I had a boyfriend that gave me an ultimatum between doingLicorice Pizzaand staying with him,” she says. “I obviously made the right choice...” By this point it has become clear that Danielle is good at bowling, Este and Alana are OK, and I am terrible. Danielle knocks out a strike and walks back casually. “That does not happen a lot,” she says, right before nailing another one. When Alana and Este bowl well, they do victory dances on the spot. “Uh, uh, body roll, body roll,” Este raps as she does so. Whenever I step up to the lane, they turn into supportive Soccer Dads. “You have to find your ball!” Alana says. “Form is great; itlooksgreat,” Este says. “Go lighter,” Alana says. “There we go! You got one—you got two!” After I dispatch another ball to the gutter gods, Este steps up and completes a spare. “Are we recording this fucking—should we be bowlers?!” says Alana. I’m later informed that a seven-year-old in the lane next to ours racked up much better scores than all four of us. From left. On Este: Top by Stella McCartney. On Alana: Bra, vintage. On Danielle: Bikini top by DKNY. All jeans by Levi's, vintage customised by stylist. The noteworthy changeon the production ofI Quitwas Rechtshaid’s absence. Though the band are not keen to go into the specifics of how those working and personal relationships came to an end, the music speaks volumes. “‘Relationships’ took us a very long time to make for some obvious reasons that we don’t have to get into,” says Alana, “but you can just look at the lyrics and you’ll understand why.” “I’ve always been averse to conflict,” Danielle sings on the verse, “but you really fucked with my confidence.” For the single’s artwork, the band recreated some heavily memed photographs of Nicole Kidman basking in the sunshine on the street like she’s just been told someexcellentnews, which were once reported to have been snapped by paparazzi after her divorce fromTom Cruisewas finalized. “She goes through the seven stages in five seconds, and we each picked our favorite expression that she made,” Alana says. “Our friend Terry [O’Connor] shot it walking down a random street. We were screaming.” “Guttural,” Este says. “All the things we wanted to say to get those emotions, it was the most cathartic experience,” says Alana. What is clear is that before they got to that guttural scream of freedom, Danielle had been through something very difficult. On “Everybody’s Trying to Figure Me Out,” she sings about a panic attack that she experienced after returning from tour to an empty house. “Something about being alone with myself scared the shit out of me,” Danielle wrote in an Instagram post promoting the song. “After a lot of reflecting I realized I’ve let a lot of people try and tell me how I should live my life, but I realized in making everyone else happy, I lost myself.” Elsewhere, on “Down to be Wrong”, she sings: “Boy, I crushed my whole heart trying to fit my soul into your arms.” The sisters’ mortifying dating stories might give you the wrong impression. Este was only single for a little while with the other two. A couple of years ago, she went on a blind date with a friend of a friend of a friend. “He took me to Pioneer Works in Red Hook—it’s like an art gallery that has a good beer selection and a good wine selection,” she says. “And it was great.” The two are now engaged. And Danielle is out of the horror-stories phase of dating, too. “Generally everyone’s just been super nice,” she says. In fact, the way she describes singledom, it sounds kind of… amazing. “I feel like in the last three years I’ve learned a lot about myself, being single and having a lot of solitary time,” she tells me. To encourage herself to be more social and spontaneous, she moved to New York for a period, spending time going on dates and hanging out with friends likeBabygirldirector Halina Reijn. “It was for my soul,” she says. “It was so good for me to be constantly out andmeeting people.” Did you learn anything surprising about yourself? “That I’m OK alone,” she says. “Not only OK, but so happy. Sorry to be that bitch but I’m like, really having a great time being by myself. And now, unless someone’s gonna make me so much more happy, I’m good.” “It’s the happiest she’s ever been, honestly,” Este agrees. “For sure.” “It’s nice to see sparkle and, like, energy come out of Danielle again,” says Alana. “’Cause for a long time it felt like it was kind of lost.” Este has learned some important shit too over the last few years. “I love Zoloft,” she says. “Thank God for SSRIs.” PTA has seen the change, too. “I think I’ve learned that the ecosystem of support in a family and friendships is always changing,” Anderson says. “Suddenly the strong leader is the child who needs care and comfort. Dynamics change and move all the time or sometimes they move in slow motion… But if the love and respect is there, everything usually works out. I’ve seen Alana really grow, obviously, from the baby of the family to one of the possibly great young actresses of her generation. That’s been cool to see.” “I’ve learned that I can throw a really good fucking party,” says Alana. “I’m still the baby sister that throws the ragers.” After bowling, wemake our way down Ventura Boulevard towards the vintage store. “I get a discount still,” Este says. As Danielle combs through the racks trying to find me the perfect pair of jeans, Este pulls out a T-shirt with a giant doodle of the Camel cigarettes camel on the front. “Dude… it has the pocket for the cigarettes,” she says, pointing to the sleeve. She picks up another T-shirt which reads: “I survived the Northridge Earthquake of ’94”. “Wedidsurvive this earthquake,” Este says. “We slept through it.” (Despite this, they assure me it was the mother of all San Fernando Valley earthquakes during their lifetime.) Este buys her earthquake tee; Danielle’s jeans hunt ends unsuccessfully. Before we part, our goodbye hugs are interrupted by a teenage fan, who—and I wasn’t expecting this—says, “My dad loves you so much,” and asks very sweetly if they would take a photo with her. The sisters kindly oblige. “Do you live in the Valley?” Este asks her as they line up for the picture. She does. “Yessss,” says Este. “Tell your dad we say hi.” Shortly afterwards, the Haim sisters are off, walking in tandem in the streets of the Valley once again. Back in the Italian restaurant, as we circled some of the thornier themes of the album, Alana had made clear the energy they’re moving into this new era with. “This is our ‘life is too short’ album,” she said. “I Quit. I quit feeling shitty. It’s time to have a good time.” A version of this story originally appeared in the June/July 2025 issue of British GQ with the title “Party of Three.” Haim will be at GQ Heroes in Oxfordshire, England from 2-4 July 2025. For more information and tickets, visitGQHeroes.com.
